text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's Austrian newspapers:

- Far-right Freedom Party chief Joerg Haider is planning to create his own worker's union, as he says the current ones are no good. At his party convention in western Austria he said he was confident of becoming chancellor at the next elections.
- Austria's airlines AUA, Lauda Air and Tyrolean Airways are preparing to boycott payments to Austria Control, the country's air traffic controller, as they say landing fees are too high.
- EU Commission is expected by the end of the month to demand the abolition of Austria's anonymous savings accounts, claiming they are used to launder money.
- Even though Austria has made spending cuts, more are on the cards if Austria wants to remain on course for European Monetary Union.
- Conservative People's Party chief negotiator for social affairs Martin Bartenstein says small shops should be able to open any time they like.

- Central bank president Klaus Liebscher says he is optimistic Austria would be part of EMU from the start. He also expects Austria's central bank to still play a role after the introduction of the single currency.
- The return of Die Erste savings bank into the consortium around Italian insurer EA-Generali will be decided today.
